title: What has shocked you the most about Greece? - Quora

response.answer_text: Well I’m from Istanbul and I visited Greece twice, my second visit being 2-weeks-long and covering many places just this summer, I think I’d say: The common dishes we have are actually not extremely similar anymore as we have been two separate communities for a long time and ingredients & cooking methods have evolved differently. But, “politika” version of certain dishes are almost exactly the same as what we have in Turkey (since “politika” refers to Istanbul, this only makes sense):Baklava in Greece has no pistachio (and syrup) because pistachio in Greece is found only on a single island in small amounts while in Turkey we use pistachio for many dishes from kebabs to desserts. I already knew about this but it still made me feel a bit awkward seeing something so familiar yet so different.I sadly tasted the awful difference between Greek and Turkish coffee. Sorry guys, it’s really not for me, you basically ruined it! (no offence intended, well maybe a bit) The difference between the coffee beans is not the trouble but it’s rather the method they make it in Greece nowadays. I learned from my Greek friends that at cafes, they use espresso machines to make it, preposterous! What’s wrong with cezve like the everyone has at home? Or why don’t you just buy a Turkish coffee maker from Arçelik like Greeks living near Turkey do? Jeez… To be honest, it was a big disappointment for me… Anyway, it seems that frappe and espresso are much more popular in Greece now. And from my observations it seems that the coffee culture in general has changed a lot too because when you ask for Greek coffee and then close the cup after drinking it (for “fortunetelling”, read: to kill time), people treat you like a grandmother as if it’s a dead tradition. In Turkey, this practice is still widely popular (and I like doing it, it’s fun when you do it with friends) so I was shocked to see that it’s long gone in Greece.Taverns have some minor differences. Ouzo-tsipouro-rakı are all different. Ouzo is too light in alcohol compared to rakı but turns smokey when you add water, tsipouro is just like neat rakı but it -sadly- doesn’t turn smokey when you add water. But well, it didn’t really matter much. Another difference about the taverns is that they don’t bring mezes on a large platter for you to see which is something common (and expected) in Turkey. And variety of mezes increases as you approach Turkey, at least that’s what I observed.I’m still not over the fact that you’re not supposed to flush toilet paper. I knew about this before I went there but it’s still too different for me.I had no idea it took that long to get to some popular islands by a regular ferry (express ferries and planes are at least 2x faster but also at least 2x more expensive so what choice do you have if you didn’t plan it weeks ago, right? My fault but still sad…).Drivers were not as horrible as Greeks claim them to be, I mean, have you ever seen a Turkish driver?Rebetiko songs sound very nice. They sound much like Turkish songs, or Aegean to be precise. But seriously, almost all of them are about hashish dealer priests from Bursa/Istanbul/Edirne/Izmir. Learning about the lyrics was pretty shocking.Greek islands were a bit different than I imagined, but still lived up to my expectations of beauty. I went to Syros and Mykonos and I was surprised that only small parts of the islands were inhabited. I always thought most of these islands were full of houses. As the ferry approached to the island I followed it on the map to be sure I was really on the right ferry because for a good 15 minutes I could only see barren hills with small churches built on top until I could finally see the beautiful, colourful harbour, only then I was relieved.I underestimated how up high the temples in Delphi were, they really looked much easier to climb on Instagram.For most Greeks Istanbul=food, I always -stereotypically- thought Istanbul=Constantinople=Hagia Sophia for GreeksThe extensive and beautiful collection of Benaki Museum in Athens was one of the highlights of my trip, I didn’t expect it to be that amazing, even the staff was pretty “elite”.There were gazillions of Indians, Ethiopians and Egyptians in Athens. This took me by surprise, I had no idea. I imagined Athens to be pretty homogenous but to my surprise it was rather cosmopolitan.There are a lot of priests around, I saw more priests in Greece than I ever saw imams in Turkey. And beware, they are pretty strict about male clothing as well. I wish they provided a kilt for men in shorts like they do in Turkey for tourists visiting the mosques.Guys, don’t fool yourselves, Orthodox fasting is not real fasting, what’s the purpose of it if you’re still feasting all through the day? Try the Muslim way, just sleep through the whole day without eating or drinking or literally contributing absolutely nothing to anyone’s lives and then feast at night! What a way to empathy with the poor, oh these religions…I realised some shop owners “lose interest” in you when you’re Turkish, happened only 1–2 times but it still made me feel bad, no rude words or gestures but it was a bit “tense” nevertheless. Maybe the same thing happens to some Greeks at some shops here but I wouldn’t know that.The number of words I can understand in spoken Greek is at least 100x more than what I imagined. Seriously, there are a lot of common words, even more if you’re in Thrace! And the Greek alphabet is not as hard as I imagined, the only bad part is they have like 945873 letters for “i”The way Greeks speak Turkish is exactly like how we think they do (which is pretty funny). They can say “Chicago” or “shake” but they can’t say “paşa” or “teşekkürler” with the “sh” sound.You can smoke almost everywhere. As a smoker myself I was pretty happy to see that but this level of law-enforcement better not apply to all aspects of their system.Obviously all these things were not “shocking” but they were all interesting to see so I wanted to mention them. Overall, it was a very pleasant trip. I’d rate it 4.7/5 (because of the coffee!). I’ll visit again at first chance to see the other parts of the country. If you were wondering, so far I’ve been to Alexandroupoli, Komotini, Xanthi, Kavala, Thessaloniki, Agia Triada, Athens, Piraeus, Delphi, Sounion, Loutraki, Korinth, Nafplion, Galatas, Poros, Epidavros, Mycenae, Syros and Mykonos.

Given that I have been going to the country for the past 9 years, a lot of things that initially shocked me I got used to at this point and don’t pay that much attention as I did at first. However, one thing not only shocks me but downright leaves me asking whether the same people who do this would like the same thing done to them in the middle of July/August when the Greek sun is burning at its maximum capacity. Charging to use the AC. Honestly, I have been in more than 15 countries and I have never, ever had a situation in which I had to pay to use the AC in the summer. Don’t get me wrong, I am well aware that people can sometimes crack the AC and leave it to cool down their apartments while they are on the beach and such, which does bring the bill up for those who rent out the apartments, but I still find it to be very stingy and torture. This is not a general thing in Greece, but in a lot of places you find apartments who have this rule, although there are obviously some exceptions. I always have this wish to ask those people “would you like to be without AC in the middle of the summer when temperatures go to 37 degrees?” If I wanted a sauna I would fine one where I am, and not travel 900km south to get it. That’s something I will never understand, even though we are now much more picky and never go to apartments which implement this (IMHO, unnecessary rule). And the saddest part is, there are truly some who rent out apartments who think that expecting someone to be without AC on 36 degrees is reasonable. In that case, I’d love to put that person into an apartment with no option to use it and just see how pleasant it is to be in such conditions. I love Greece, I truly do and it has become my second home, I love the people, love the food and the atmosphere - but there are some things I truly can’t comprehend to this day.
